PT J
AU BOYD, WE
AF BOYD, WE
TI METHODOLOGICAL PROBLEMS IN THE ANALYSIS OF FOSSIL NON-ARTIFACTUAL WOOD
   ASSEMBLAGES FROM ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB The analysis of fossil wood fragments is often undertaken in relation to the archaeological excavation of a site. However, such analysis does not yet appear to have the strong methodological foundation that the investigation of many other classes of palaeoenvironmental evidence (e.g. seeds and pollen) have. Consequently, it is difficult to evaluate the value of fossil wood analysis at an archaeological site. Using data regarding non-artifactual wood assemblages at one site in southern Scotland [UK] the relative merits of possible analysis are described and discussed. The results from such analyses tend to fall into two broad groups: (1) those of relatively high reliability, and (2) those of relatively low reliability. These results in the former group are often based on moderately secure methodology and tend to provide relatively non-interpretative information (e.g. species lists). On the other hand, those in the latter group are more often based on insecure interpretive  methodology and provide relatively more stimulating information, such as evidence for prehistoric woodland management. There are many reasons for this situation, and these are discussed. In conclusion, it is argued that to increase the reliability of results in the second group (in particular), a full understanding of the taphonomy of non-artifactual fossil wood assemblages is needed, and that once this is available attention can then be paid, as elsewhere in environmental archaeology, to the problems of providing statistically valid samples for analysis.
RP NO RIVERS COLL ADV EDUC, LISMORE, NSW 2480, AUSTRALIA.
RI Boyd, William/B-5103-2011
OI Boyd, William/0000-0002-8466-4669

TI VARIABILITY IN BONE ASSEMBLAGE FORMATION FROM HADZA HUNTING, SCAVENGING,

SO JOURNAL OF ANTHROPOLOGICAL ARCHAEOLOGY

PT J
AU BETHELL, PH
   SMITH, JU
AF BETHELL, PH
   SMITH, JU
TI TRACE-ELEMENT ANALYSIS OF AN INHUMATION FROM SUTTON HOO, USING
   INDUCTIVELY COUPLED PLASMA EMISSION-SPECTROMETRY - AN EVALUATION OF THE
   TECHNIQUE APPLIED TO ANALYSIS OF ORGANIC RESIDUES
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB A project centred on the Anglo-Saxon burial ground at Sutton Hoo, Suffolk, England, has a brief to identify and chemically characterize organic residues from archaeological contexts. Very acid sandy soils at Sutton Hoo provide an extreme of preservation in which organic material has been found as mere traces. A quick and simple analytical method is required to find a chemical "signature" for the various visually identifiable organic residues (e.g. human remains, wood, etc), and hence permit identification of unknown, or even non-visible traces of organic material. To this end, inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry was used to analyse the elemental/trace-elemental content of a number of samples from an inhumation at Sutton Hoo, to see if the organic remains could be clearly differentiated from the grave fill without recourse to more complex organic analysis. The exercise is part of a much wider attempt to understand better the relationship between preservation and burial environment, and work towards a quantification of that relationship, in order ultimately to create a predictive tool for field archaeology.
C1 UNIV READING, DEPT SOIL SCI, READING RG6 2AH, BERKS, ENGLAND.
C3 University of Reading
RP UNIV BIRMINGHAM, BUFAU, POB 363, BIRMINGHAM B15 2TT, W MIDLANDS, ENGLAND.
RI Smith, Jo/F-7763-2012

   BARKER H, 1975, SUTTON HOO SHIP BURI, V1, P550
   BIEK L, 1957, P PREHIST SOC, V23, P137

   DIMBLEBY GW, 1975, SUTTON HOO SHIP BURI, V1

PT J
AU HILLSON, SW
   JONES, BK
AF HILLSON, SW
   JONES, BK
TI INSTRUMENTS FOR MEASURING SURFACE PROFILES - AN APPLICATION IN THE STUDY
   OF ANCIENT HUMAN TOOTH CROWN SURFACES
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB Two computer-interfaced instruments have been developed to measure the microscopic features of surfaces. One is based on a stylus which tracks across the surface being studied, while the other is based upon a measuring microscope. Both have wide potential applications within archaeology, but they are currently being used to measure layered structures on the surface of ancient human tooth crowns and programs have been developed to analyse the results.

PT J
AU BAILEY, GN
   LEWIN, J
   MACKLIN, MG
   WOODWARD, JC
AF BAILEY, GN
   LEWIN, J
   MACKLIN, MG
   WOODWARD, JC
TI THE OLDER FILL OF THE VOIDOMATIS VALLEY, NORTH-WEST GREECE AND ITS
   RELATIONSHIP TO THE PALEOLITHIC ARCHAEOLOGY AND GLACIAL HISTORY OF THE
   REGION
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB Late-Quaternary alluvial deposits in Mediterranean valleys have been divided into "Older" and "Younger" Fills. The Older Fills are generally coarse, are commonly calcreted and may be associated with isolated Palaeolithic artefacts of uncertain provenance. In broad terms the Older Fills were clearly deposited during cold stages of the Pleistocene. owever, it has rarely proved possible to establish a more precise dating and corelation with specific Pleistocene stages, or a more precise identification of depositional environmens and their relationship with, and impact on, human activity and land-use. The Voidomatis River of northwest Greece contains four main alluvial terraces which can be distinguished by lithological and mineralogical techniques. One of these, the Aristi unit, can be directly linked with glacial deposits in the headwaters. Comparison of dates for the Aristi unit with dated evidence of late Upper Paleolithic sites in the lower reaches of the river gives a basis for assessing the impact of alluvial history on the Palaeolithic occupation of the area.
C1 UNIV COLL WALES, INST EARTH STUDIES, ABERYSTWYTH SY23 3DB, WALES.
   UNIV CAMBRIDGE, GODWIN LAB, SUB DEPT QUATERNARY RES, CAMBRIDGE CB2 3RS, ENGLAND.
   UNIV NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE, DEPT GEOG, NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE NE1 7RU, TYNE & WEAR, ENGLAND.
C3 Aberystwyth University; University of Cambridge

PT J
AU WILSON, SM
   MELNICK, DJ
AF WILSON, SM
   MELNICK, DJ
TI MODELING RANDOMNESS IN LOCATIONAL ARCHAEOLOGY
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB Many analytical techniques in locational archaeology and spatial geography involve comparing observed distributions of point patterns with theoretically-modelled random distributions. In this paper we suggest that comparing observed data with large numbers of empirically generated random distributions offers a more accurate, robust, and intuitively obvious estimate of deviations from randomness in distributional data. Specifically, the nearest-neighbour and linear nearest-neighbour statistics  are discussed, and a randomization method of generating random patterns of data is applied to both theoretical models of point pattern distributions and to archaeological data. We have found that the theoretical values associated with a random point distribution (e.g. about 1.00 for the nearest-neighbour statistic) only hold for very specific site geometries and that the randomization approach, because it makes no assumption about the shape of a region, is more widely applicable to real  archaeological data. Similarly, the randomization routine we offer provides a more robust test of the statistical significance of deviations from randomness, which are not burdened by the underlying assumptions of statistical models regularly applied to this question.
C1 COLUMBIA UNIV, DEPT ANTHROPOL, NEW YORK, NY 10027 USA.
C3 Columbia University
RP UNIV TEXAS, DEPT ANTHROPOL, AUSTIN, TX 78712 USA.

PT J
AU CARTER, SP
AF CARTER, SP
TI THE STRATIFICATION AND TAPHONOMY OF SHELLS IN CALCAREOUS SOILS -
   IMPLICATIONS FOR LAND SNAIL ANALYSIS IN ARCHAEOLOGY
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB The ecological interpretation of land snails from buried soils has depended on the assumption that assemblages are age-stratified and not seriously distorted by differential destruction. The temporal and ecological resolutions of assemblages are determined by taphonomic processes controlling the incorporation, mixing and subsequent destruction of shells in the soil. This paper describes those soil processes affecting snail assemblages in Britain and attempts to quantify their effects. It is  concluded that, except in certain restricted circumstances, the temporal and ecological resolutions of land snail assemblages in buried soils are poor.

PT J
AU SCHELVIS, J
AF SCHELVIS, J
TI THE RECONSTRUCTION OF LOCAL ENVIRONMENTS ON THE BASIS OF REMAINS OF
   ORIBATID MITES (ACARI, ORIBATIDA)
SO JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
AB A method is presented for reconstructing the local environment on the basis of the remains of oribatid mites. The distribution of the species over 20 ecological groups, of which the species composition as well as the preferred habitats are given, forms the basis of this reconstruction. It is concluded that these reconstructions, and especially comparisons in time and/or in space between these reconstruction, provide useful information on past ecological conditions. Some additional applications  of the study of mite remains in archaeology (Acaroarchaeology) are also presented.
RP STATE UNIV GRONINGEN, INST BIOL ARCHAEOL, POSTST 6, 9712 ER GRONINGEN, NETHERLANDS.

   Heydt Johann Wolfgang., 1744, Allerneuester geographisch- und topographischer Schau-Platz von Africa und Ost-Indien, oder Ausfhrliche und wahrhafte Vorstellung und Beschreibung von den wichtigsten der Hollndisch-Ost-Indischen Compagnie in Africa und Asia zugehrigen Lndere, Ksten und Insulen, in accuraten See- und Land-Karten, nicht weniger Der darinn befindlichen Stdte, Hfen, Castellen, Factoreyen, Schlsser, und Schiffs-Werffe, Packhuser, Kirchen, Lust- und Wohnhuser, auch andern publiquen Gebuden, und Grten, nebst den damit verknpften Geographischen Merkwrdigkeiten, wie auch einem Anhang oder Historischer Beschreibung der Reise des Verfassers von Holland nach Ost-Indien, und von dar widerum zu ruck in sein Vaterland, samt einem vollstndigen Register des gantzen Wercks. In CXV sauber und nach dem leben gezeichneten Prospecten getreulich und aus eigner Erfahrung entworffen, aufgemessen und mitgetheilet von J.W.H., Hochgrffl. Hohenloh-Schillingsfrstl. Bau-Director und Geometer. PT J
AU ZANGGER, E
AF ZANGGER, E
TI PREHISTORIC COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS IN GREECE - THE VANISHED LANDSCAPES OF
   DIMINI BAY AND LAKE LERNA
SO JOURNAL OF FIELD ARCHAEOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Two completely vanished environments in Greece, a shallow coastal bay at Dimini near Volos and a large freshwater lake near Lerna south of Argos, were found and reconstructed with over 200 auger and drill cores.  Similarities between the coastal landscapes of modern Volos and Argos with respect to topography and settlement history are attributable to comparable geological settings and Holocene environmental histories; for example, at both places active faulting has played a significant role and shoreline shifts have determined site locations.  Near Volos the sea extended 3 km farther inland during the middle Holocene, reaching the base of Dimini Magoula (tell).  After the Neolithic the shore gradually receded, resulting in a seaward shift of settlements, thus explaining the presence of several single-component sites in the area.  Near Argos, the former presence of a large freshwater lagoon, named Lake Lerna, has been deduced from subsurface deposits.  The lake was separated from the open sea by a beach barrier.  It originated when the postglacial sea level rise reached its culmination point and extended over a diameter of 4.7 km in the Early Bronze Age.  Increased soil erosion then caused a rapid silting, but remnants of Lake Lerna persisted until the last century.  Anthropological studies have shown how the inhabitants of this coastal marsh have suffered from malaria in the past.  It may be that the story of the legendary fight between Herakles and the Lernaean Hydra reflects the struggle of the Lernaean people as they tried to change the inhospitable environment by draining the lake.
RP ZANGGER, E (corresponding author), UNIV CAMBRIDGE,DEPT EARTH SCI,DOWNING ST,CAMBRIDGE CB2 3EQ,ENGLAND.
